notes: Capcom's first hit game

name: Asteroids
notes: Atari's most successful coin-operated game.

name: Battlezone
notes: Custom cabinet with novel dual-joystick controls, using two 2-way joysticks for movement, and periscope-like viewer.

name: Berzerk
notes: Early use of speech synthesis was also translated into other languages in Europe.

name: BurgerTime
notes: Original title changed from Hamburger when brought to the U.S. from Japan

name: Centipede
notes: One of the first games to use trackball control, vertical monitor orientation.

name: Defender
notes: Was predicted to be outsold by Rally-X, but Defender trounced it, going on to sell 60,000 units

name: Dig Dug
notes: Rated the sixth most popular coin-operated video game of all time

name: Donkey Kong
notes: Laid foundations for platform game genre as well as visual storytelling in video games, and introduced Mario, the character who would become Nintendo's mascot.

name: Donkey Kong Junior
notes: The last time Nintendo's mascot, Mario, was featured as an antagonist in a Nintendo game

name: Dragon's Lair
notes: An early laserdisc video game, which allowed film-quality animation in the game.

name: Elevator Action
notes: An action game where the protagonist must traverse the building's numerous levels via a series of elevators and escalators while acquiring documents

name: Frogger
notes: Novel gameplay free of fighting and shooting

name: Galaga
notes: Leapfrogged its predecessor, Galaxian, in popularity

name: Galaxian
notes: Created to compete with Space Invaders. Featured a color screen and had aliens attack in swooping formation.

name: Gorf
notes: Consisted of several levels, some of which were clones of other popular games. Featured synthesized speech.

name: Gravitar
notes: Not popular in the arcades due to its difficulty, but historically significant as the gameplay inspired many popular clones like Thrust and Oids.

name: Gyruss
notes: Often remembered for its musical score that plays throughout the game, Bach's "Toccata and Fugue in D minor"

name: Joust
notes: Contained a design flaw so popular it was intentionally touted by producers as a "hidden feature"

name: Jungle King
notes: An early side-scrolling (and diagonal-scrolling) platformer, featuring vine-swinging mechanics, run & jump sequences, climbing hills, and swimming.

name: Lunar Lander
notes: First Atari game to use vector graphics

name: Mappy
notes: Featured early side-scrolling platforming action

name: Mario Bros.
notes: The first game featuring Nintendo's mascot, Mario, along with his brother, Luigi

name: Missile Command
notes: One of the first games to use trackball control. Originally to have a localities-option that named the cities, but was determined too complicated.

name: Moon Patrol
notes: The first arcade game to feature parallax scrolling.

name: Ms. Pac-Man
notes: Created from a bootlegged hack of Pac-Man.

name: Pac-Man
notes: One of the most popular and influential games, it had the first gaming mascot, established maze chase genre, opened gaming to female audiences, and introduced power-ups and cutscenes.

name: Paperboy
notes: Novel controls and high resolution display

name: Pengo
notes: A maze game set in an environment full of ice blocks, which can be used by the player's penguin, who can slide them to attack enemies.

name: Phoenix
notes: Notable for its haunting melody accompaniment. One of the first games to feature a boss battle.

name: Pole Position
notes: A racing video game that popularized the third-person "rear-view racer format" player perspective

name: Punch-Out!!
notes: A boxing fighting game featuring digitized voices, dual monitors, a third-person perspective, and 3D wire-frame graphics.

name: Q*bert
notes: Became one of the most merchandised arcade games behind Pac-Man and Donkey Kong.

name: Qix
notes: The objective is to fence off a supermajority of the play area

name: Rally-X
notes: First game to feature a "bonus" round, background music, and a radar. When released, was predicted to outsell two other new releases: Pac-Man and Defender.

name: Robotron 2084
notes: Featured novel dual joystick gameplay

name: Scramble
notes: Horizontal scrolling shooter game

name: Space Invaders
notes: Considered the game that revolutionized the video game industry. The first blockbuster video game, it established the shoot 'em up genre, and has influenced most shooter games since.

name: Spy Hunter
notes: Memorable for its music, "The Peter Gunn Theme", that plays throughout the game

name: Star Castle
notes: The colors of the rings and screen are provided by a transparent plastic screen overlay

name: Star Trek
notes: Space combat sim featuring five different controls, six different enemies, and 40 different simulation levels. One of the most elaborate vector games released.

name: Star Wars
notes: Features several digitized samples of actors' voices from the movie

name: Tapper
notes: Originally aligned with American beer Budweiser, was revamped as Root Beer Tapper, so as not to be construed as attempting to peddle alcohol to minors

name: Tempest
notes: One of the first games to use a color vector display

name: Time Pilot
notes: Time travel themed aerial combat game with free-roaming gameplay in open air space that scrolls indefinitely in all directions, with player's plane always remaining centered.

name: Track & Field
notes: The first Olympic-themed sports game.

name: Tron
notes: Earned more than the film it was based on

name: Vanguard
notes: Early scrolling shooter that scrolls in multiple directions, and allows shooting in four directions, using four direction buttons, similar to dual-stick controls.

name: Wizard of Wor
notes: Game featured maze-like dungeons infested with monsters and aliens.

name: Xevious
notes: The first arcade video game to have a TV commercial. It was also responsible for popularizing vertical scrolling shooters.

name: Zaxxon
notes: First game to employ isometric axonometric projection, which the game was named after
